newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Some Russian shares active but many being held.
newsitem.headline: Some Russian shares active but many being held.

text.p: A handful of Russian share issues reacted to company specific news in afternoon trading on Monday, but dealers said the market as a whole was quietening down and they preferred to hold rather than sell at the slow end of year.
The Russian Trading System index closed up about one percent at 189.73 on $10.5 million market turnover, a relatively low volume which has become average over the last week.
Surgutneftegaz preferred shares firmed to $0.3050 from $0.2935 after the oil company announced plans to issue an American Depositary Receipt specifically for the prefs.
Regional utility Murmanskelektrosvyaz jumped over 40 percent to $15.00 on 10,000 shares trading for the day, fairly typical of price activity in illiquid shares 'discovered' by investors.
But utility Mosenergo, the bellwether of the share market, did not register a single trade on the Russian Trading System.
"Over the next month and a half we will have dramatic stock-specific moves but no marketwide moves, barring major events," said Troika-Dialog's Terry Olin.

Some traders predicted the market would stay in a five percent range on either side of current prices until year's end as many investors sat on shares, indicating a lengthening investment horizon, waiting for new funds to move the market.

Peter Kizenko of ING Barings said many second-tier buyers with six-month or longer holding horizons would likely avoid new buying rather than take profits, which was often the case in past activity slowdowns.
"A lot of buyers are stepping away because they overheated it," he said, adding that some were still ready to buy, anticipating much sharper price appreciation in the new year.

Olin said regional telecoms were showing some profit-taking, though, which he linked to news that Russia was no longer using London-based investment bank N.M. Rothschild as adviser on sale of a stake in telecoms holding company AO Svyazinvest.
"The market is afraid that since a handful of powerful Russian banks will manage the Svyazinvest offering, there may be no injection of capital into the firm and its regional telecoms," he said.
